p: The expression of bacterial virulence factors is generally coordinated by quorum sensing (QS) mechanisms, a cell-to-cell communication system that allows bacteria to detect their population density by producing and perceiving diffusible signal molecules that synchronize common behaviors [ 6]. Depending on bacteria species, QS regulates the production of virulence factors, motilities, and/or biofilm formation. Thus, the disruption of QS signaling, also termed quorum quenching (QQ), appears as interesting adjuvant strategies in the fight against bacterial infections [ 9].
